Here. I made two intuitive explanations.  Imagine the volume of revolution.its just the bump on the flat surface with Max value at the origin and  decreasing strictly to infinity.(but it never touches the surface). pick a point on the 3d diagram and make a 2 slices  vertically and side wards perpendicular to the flat surface.these slices are perpendicular and having equal area .becoz the volume is symmetrical about vertical and sideward axis(((V=Q^2)).this is becoz the 2d curve we used for revolution is symmetric about vertical axis.  2...Imagine the following.take the volume of revolution and cut vertically into n slices..these slices are 2D as n tends to infinity.  The slice which passes through the origin is of same size as that of the one we used for revolution but they are in 2 perpendicular plane.  As we move away from the origin((side wards))the size of the slices got reduced by the factorC.  Then What is the factor?.the factor is the curve in the vertical plane..  (Go back to the diagram in the lecture) The slice at the distance y=b is diminished by the factor C=(e^-b)^2.....  And for any slice C =C=(e^-y)^2..here c is a variable constant.  Finally ,r gives us the information about the diminishing factor..++++.I am a student and interested in learning..I interested in learning with other people and I believe in team work..contact  me if u r interested  Gmail: karthi211421@gmail.com

x and y are independent. It is z = e^–r^2 that depends on both x and y. More precisely, z = e^–(x^2+y^2). I'm not sure why the professor avoided mentioning this. I guess it is because he didn't want to make the problem seem like a problem in multivariable calculus. Nonetheless, I think it would have made the discussion clearer.

The value of a definite integral doesn’t depend on the variable it contains. That’s why he calls it a “dummy” variable: you integrate over many values of it and that gives you a certain number. So there’s no sense in which that number varies as the integration variable varies. So whether you integrate dx or dy, you get the same number. Call it Q. Then when you multiply the integral dx by the integral dy you get Q squared.
No. Circumflex of an ellipse is 4*a*E(e), where a is the bigger semiaxis, e is the excentricity and E(k) is elliptical integral of second kind IIRC. Check wikipedia.

You cannot assume that   "1 = .9999999999999999999999999"  because that is clearly false.  1 = .9999999999999.... infinitely repeating.   "then why does: 1/3 = .333333333333333333333"  It doesn't. See above.  "3*(1/3) = .9999999999999999999999999999"  Wrong.

The textbook listed for this course is: Simmons, George F. Calculus with Analytic Geometry. 2nd ed. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill, October 1, 1996. ISBN: 9780070576421. (http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0070576424/ref=nosim/mitopencourse-20) For more course information and materials see the course on MIT OpenCourseWare at: http://ocw.mit.edu/18-01F06.
